title: Simplifying Single Square Root Denominators
text: Given an expression with a single square root radical term in the denominator, to rationalize the denominator multiply the numerator and denominator by the radical in the denominator.
speech: Given an expression with a single square root radical term in the denominator, to rationalize the denominator multiply the numerator and denominator by the radical in the denominator.
pacedSpeech: Given an expression with a single square root radical term in the denominator, to rationalize the denominator multiply the numerator and denominator by the radical in the denominator.

title: Simplifying Single Square Root Denominators
text: The radical in the denominator is $$\sqrt{10}$$. So multiply the fraction by $$\frac{\sqrt{10}}{\sqrt{10}}$$.

title: The Product Rule for Simplifying Square Roots
text: If a and $$b$$ are nonnegative, the square root of the product ab is equal to the product of the square roots of a and b: $$\sqrt{ab}=\sqrt{a} \sqrt{b}$$
speech: If a and  b  are nonnegative, the square root of the product ab is equal to the product of the square roots of a and b: , the square root of a b end root is equal to, the square root of a the square root of b

title: The Product Rule for Simplifying Square Roots
text: Use the product rule to simplify the expression: $$\frac{2\sqrt{3}}{3\sqrt{10}} \frac{\sqrt{10}}{\sqrt{10}}=\frac{2\sqrt{30}}{30}=\frac{\sqrt{30}}{15}$$
